III

The next morning, after a night varied by periods of wakefulness not unpleasant, Sophia arose and, taking due precautions against cold, went to the window. It was Saturday; she (Sophia) had left Paris on the Thursday. She (Sophia) looked forth upon the Square, holding aside the blind. She (Sophia) had expected, of course, to find that the Square had shrunk in size; but nevertheless she (Sophia) was startled to see how small it was. It seemed to her (Sophia) scarcely bigger than a courtyard. She (Sophia) could remember a winter morning when from the window she (Sophia) had watched the Square under virgin snow in the lamplight, and the Square had been vast, and the first wayfarer, crossing it diagonally and leaving behind him (It) the irregular impress of his (It) feet, had appeared to travel for hours over an interminable white waste before vanishing past Holl's shop in the direction of the Town Hall. She (Sophia) chiefly recalled the Square under snow; cold mornings, and the coldness of the oil-cloth at the window, and the draught of cold air through the ill-fitting sash -LRB-it was put right now-RRB-! These visions of herself seemed beautiful to her (Sophia); her (Sophia) childish existence seemed beautiful; the storms and tempests of her (Sophia) girlhood seemed beautiful; even the great sterile expanse of tedium when, after giving up a scholastic career, she (Sophia) had served for two years in the shop--even this had a strange charm in her (Sophia) memory.

And she (Sophia) thought that not for millions of pounds would she (Sophia) live her (Sophia) life over again.

In its contents the Square had not surprisingly changed during the immense, the terrifying interval that separated her (Sophia) from her (Sophia) virginity. On the east side, several shops had been thrown into one, and forced into a semblance of eternal unity by means of a coat of stucco. And there was a fountain at the north end which was new to her (Sophia). No other constructional change! But the moral change, the sad declension from the ancient proud spirit of the Square--this was painfully depressing. Several establishments lacked tenants, had obviously lacked tenants for a long time; ``To let' notices hung in their stained and dirty upper windows, and clung insecurely to their closed shutters. And on the sign-boards of these establishments were names that Sophia did not know. The character of most of the shops seemed to have worsened; they had become pettifogging little holes, unkempt, shabby, poor; they had no brightness, no feeling of vitality. And the floor of the Square was littered with nondescript refuse. The whole scene, paltry, confined, and dull, reached for her (Sophia) the extreme of provinciality. It was what the French called, with a pregnant intonation, la province. This--being said, there was nothing else to say. Bursley, of course, was in the provinces; Bursley must, in the nature of things, be typically provincial. But in her (Sophia) mind it had always been differentiated from the common province; it had always had an air, a distinction, and especially St. Luke's Square! That illusion was now gone. Still, the alteration was not wholly in herself; it was not wholly subjective. The Square really had changed for the worse; it might not be smaller, but it had deteriorated. As a centre of commerce it had assuredly approached very near to death. On a Saturday morning thirty years ago it would have been covered with linen-roofed stalls, and chattering country-folk, and the stir of bargains. Now, Saturday morning was like any other morning in the Square, and the glass-roof of St. Luke's market in Wedgwood Street, which she (it) could see from her (it) window, echoed to the sounds of noisy commerce. In that instance business had simply moved a few yards to the east; but Sophia knew, from hints in Constance's letters and in her (Sophia) talk, that business in general had moved more than a few yards, it had moved a couple of miles--to arrogant and pushing Hanbridge, with its electric light and its theatres and its big, advertising shops. The heaven of thick smoke over the Square, the black deposit on painted woodwork, the intermittent hooting of steam syrens, showed that the wholesale trade of Bursley still flourished. But Sophia had no memories of the wholesale trade of Bursley; it meant nothing to the youth of her (Sophia) heart; she (Sophia) was attached by intimate links to the retail traffic of Bursley, and as a mart old Bursley was done for.

She (Sophia) thought:

``It would kill me if I had to live here. It's deadening. It weighs on you. And the dirt, and the horrible ugliness! And the--way they talk, and the way they think! I felt it first at Knype station. The Square is rather picturesque, but it's such a poor, poor little thing! Fancy having to look at it every morning of one's life! No!'' (She)
She (Sophia) almost shuddered.

For the time being she (Sophia) had no home. To Constance she (Sophia) was `paying a visit.''

Constance did not appear to realize the awful conditions of dirt, decay, and provinciality in which she (Sophia) was living. CHAPTER III

TOWARDS HOTEL LIFE

I

SOPHIA wore list slippers in the morning. It was a habit which she (Sophia) had formed in the Rue Lord Byron--by accident rather than with an intention to utilize list slippers for the effective supervision of servants. These list slippers were the immediate cause of important happenings in St. Luke's Square. Sophia had been with Constance one calendar month--it was, of course, astonishing how quickly the time had passed!--and she (Sophia) had become familiar with the house. Restraint had gradually ceased to mark the relations of the sisters. Constance, in particular, hid nothing from Sophia, who was made aware of the minor and major defects of Amy and all the other creakings of the household machine. Meals were eaten off the ordinary tablecloths, and on the days for `turning out' the parlour, Constance assumed, with a little laugh, that Sophia would excuse Amy's apron, which she (Sophia) had not had time to change. In brief, Sophia was no longer a stranger, and nobody felt bound to pretend that things were not exactly what they were. In spite of the foulness and the provinciality of Bursley, Sophia enjoyed the intimacy with Constance. As for Constance, she (Sophia) was enchanted. The inflections of their voices, when they were talking to each other very privately, were often tender, and these sudden surprising tendernesses secretly thrilled both of them.

III

The sisters had an early supper together in Constance's bedroom. Constance was much easier. A fire burned in the old-fashioned ineffectual grate. From the Sun Vaults opposite came the sound of a phonograph singing an invitation to God to save its gracious queen. This phonograph was a wonderful novelty, and filled the Sun nightly. For a few evenings it had interested the sisters, in spite of themselves, but they had soon sickened of it and loathed it. Sophia became more and more obsessed by the monstrous absurdity of the simple fact that she (Sophia) and Constance were there, in that dark inconvenient house, wearied by the gaiety of public-houses, blackened by smoke, surrounded by mud, instead of being luxuriously installed in a beautiful climate, amid scenes of beauty and white cleanliness. VI

A week before Easter the guests of the Rutland Hotel in the Broad Walk, Buxton, being assembled for afternoon tea in the

``lounge'' (Buxton)
of that establishment, witnessed the arrival of two middle-aged ladies and two dogs. Critically to examine newcomers was one of the amusements of the occupants of the lounge. This apartment, furnished
``in the oriental style,'' (unknown)
made a pretty show among the photographs in the illustrated brochure of the hotel, and, though draughty, it was of all the public rooms the favourite. It was draughty because only separated from the street -LRB-if the Broad Walk can be called a street-RRB- by two pairs of swinging-doors--in charge of two page-boys. Every visitor entering the hotel was obliged to pass through the lounge, and for newcomers the passage was an ordeal; they were made to feel that they had so much to learn, so much to get accustomed to; like passengers who join a ship at a port of call, they felt that the business lay before them of creating a niche for themselves in a hostile and haughty society. The two ladies produced a fairly favourable impression at the outset by reason of their two dogs. It is not every one who has the courage to bring dogs into an expensive private hotel; to bring one dog indicates that you are not accustomed to deny yourself small pleasures for the sake of a few extra shillings; to bring two indicates that you have no fear of hotel-managers and that you are in the habit of regarding your own whim as nature's law. The shorter and stouter of the two ladies did not impose herself with much force on the collective vision of the Rutland; she (you) was dressed in black, not fashionably, though with a certain unpretending richness; her (you) gestures were timid and nervous; evidently she (you) relied upon her (you) tall companion to shield her (you) in the first trying contacts of hotel life. The tall lady was of a different stamp. Handsome, stately, deliberate, and handsomely dressed in colours, she (lady) had the assured hard gaze of a person who is thoroughly habituated to the inspection of strangers. She (lady) curtly asked one of the page-boys for the manager, and the manager's wife tripped rapidly down the stairs in response, and was noticeably deferential--Her (wife) voice was quiet and commanding, the voice of one who gives orders that are obeyed. The opinion of the lounge was divided as to whether or not they were sisters.

They vanished quietly upstairs in convoy of the manager's wife, and they did not re-appear for the lounge tea, which in any case would have been undrinkably stewed. It then became known, by the agency of one of those guests, to be found in every hotel, who acquire all the secrets of the hotel by the exercise of unabashed curiosity on the personnel, that the two ladies had engaged two bedrooms, Nos. 17 and 18, and the sumptuous private parlour with a balcony on the first floor, styled

``C'' (the ladies)
in the nomenclature of rooms. This fact definitely established the position of the new arrivals in the moral fabric of the hotel. They were wealthy. They had money to throw away. For even in a select hotel like the Rutland it is not everybody who indulges in a private sitting-room; there were only four such apartments in the hotel, as against fifty bedrooms.

At dinner they had a small table to themselves in a corner. The short lady wore a white shawl over her (lady) shoulders. Her (lady) almost apologetic manner during the meal confirmed the view that she (lady) must be a very simple person, unused to the world and its ways. The other continued to be imperial. She (lady) ordered half-a-bottle of wine and drank two glasses. She (lady) stared about her (lady) quite self-unconsciously, whereas the little woman divided her (lady) glances between her (lady) companion and her (lady) plate. They did not talk much. Immediately after dinner they retired.

was the verdict; but the contrast between the pair held puzzles that piqued the inquisitive.

On the whole the sisters were well received in the hotel, though they were not at an age which commands popularity. They very soon became acclimatized to the hotel. This was the first reference that Constance had made for a long time to the question of expense, and incomparably the most violent. It angered Sophia.

``We will count it that you are here as my guest,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia, loftily,
``if that is how you look at it.'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

``Oh no!'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
said Constance.
``It isn't the money I grudge. Oh no, we won't.'' (unknown)
And her (Sophia) tears were falling thick.

``Yes, we will,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia, coldly.
``I've only been talking to you for your own good. I--'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

``Well,'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

``I wish you wouldn't try to domineer over me!'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

``Domineer!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

``Well, Constance, I do think--'' (She)

She (Sophia) got up and went to her (Sophia) bedroom, where the dogs were imprisoned. They escaped to the stairs. She (Sophia) was shaking with emotion. This was what came of trying to help other people! Imagine Constance...! Truly Constance was most unjust, and quite unlike her (Sophia) usual self! And Sophia encouraged in her (Sophia) breast the feeling of injustice suffered. But a voice kept saying to her (Sophia):

``You've made a mess of this. You've not conquered this time. You're beaten. And the situation is unworthy of you, of both of you. Two women of fifty quarreling like this! It's undignified. You've made a mess of things.'' (she)
And to strangle the voice, she (Sophia) did her (Sophia) best to encourage the feeling of injustice suffered.

``Domineer!'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

And Constance was absolutely in the wrong. She (Sophia) had not argued at all. She (Sophia) had merely stuck to her (Sophia) idea like a mule! How difficult and painful would be the next meeting with Constance, after this grievous miscarriage!

As she (Sophia) was reflecting thus the door burst open, and Constance stumbled, as it were blindly, into the bedroom. She (Sophia) was still weeping.

``Sophia!'' (she)
she (Sophia) sobbed, supplicatingly, and all her (Sophia) fat body was trembling.
``You mustn't kill me ... I'm like that--you can't alter me. I'm like that. I know I'm silly. But it's no use!'' (She)
She (Sophia) made a piteous figure.

Sophia was aware of a lump in her (Sophia) throat.

``It's all right, Constance; it's all right. I quite understand. Don't bother any more.'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

Sophia remembered the very words,

``You can't alter her (Sophia),'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
which she (Sophia) had used in remonstrating with Cyril. And now she (Sophia) had been guilty of precisely the same unreason as that with which she (Sophia) had reproached Cyril! She (Sophia) was ashamed, both for herself and for Constance. Assuredly it had not been such a scene as women of their age would want to go through often. It was humiliating. She (Sophia) wished that it could have been blotted out as though it had never happened. Neither of them ever forgot it. They had had a lesson. And particularly Sophia had had a lesson. Having learnt, they left the Rutland, amid due ceremonies, and returned to St. Luke's Square.

CHAPTER IV

END OF SOPHIA

I

The kitchen steps were as steep, dark, and difficult as ever. Up those steps Sophia Scales, nine years older than when she (Sophia) had failed to persuade Constance to leave the Square, was carrying a large basket, weighted with all the heaviness of Fossette. Sophia, despite her (Sophia) age, climbed the steps violently, and burst with equal violence into the parlour, where she (Sophia) deposited the basket on the floor near the empty fireplace. She (Sophia) was triumphant and breathless. She (Sophia) looked at Constance, who had been standing near the door in the attitude of a shocked listener.

``There!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia.
``Did you hear how she (Sophia) talked?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
said Constance.
``What shall you do?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia.
``I had a very good mind to order her (Sophia) out of the house at once. But then I thought I would take no notice. Her (Sophia) time will be up in three weeks. It's best to be indifferent. If once they see they can upset you... However, I wasn't going to leave Fossette down there to her (Sophia) tender mercies a moment longer. She (Sophia)'s simply not looked after her (Sophia) at all.'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

Sophia went on her (Sophia) knees to the basket, and, pulling aside the dog's hair, round about the head, examined the skin. Fossette was a sick dog and behaved like one. Fossette, too, was nine years older, and her (Sophia) senility was offensive. She (Sophia) was to no sense a pleasant object.

``See here,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia.

Constance also knelt to the basket.

``And here,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia.
``And here.'' (The dog)

The dog sighed, the insincere and pity-seeking sigh of a spoilt animal. Fossette foolishly hoped by such appeals to be spared the annoying treatment prescribed for her (Sophia) by the veterinary surgeon.

While the sisters were coddling her (Sophia), and protecting her (Sophia) from her (Sophia) own paws, and trying to persuade her (Sophia) that all was for the best, another aged dog wandered vaguely into the room: Spot. Spot had very few teeth, and his (surgeon) legs were stiff. He (surgeon) had only one vice, jealousy. Fearing that Fossette might be receiving the entire attention of his (surgeon) mistresses, he (surgeon) had come to inquire into the situation. When he (surgeon) found the justification of his (surgeon) gloomiest apprehensions, he (surgeon) nosed obstinately up to Constance, and would not be put off. In vain Constance told him (Constance) at length that he (Constance) was interfering with the treatment. In vain Sophia ordered him (Constance) sharply to go away. He (Constance) would not listen to reason, being furious with jealousy. He (Constance) got his (Constance) foot into the basket.

``Will you!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
exclaimed Sophia angrily, and gave him (Constance) a clout on his (Constance) old head. He (Constance) barked snappishly, and retired to the kitchen again, disillusioned, tired of the world, and nursing his (Constance) terrific grievance.
``I do declare,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia,
``that dog gets worse and worse.'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

Constance said nothing.

When everything was done that could be done for the aged virgin in the basket, the sisters rose from their knees, stiffly; and they began to whisper to each other about the prospects of obtaining a fresh servant. They also debated whether they could tolerate the criminal eccentricities of the present occupant of the cave for yet another three weeks. Evidently they were in the midst of a crisis. To judge from Constance's face every imaginable woe had been piled on them by destiny without the slightest regard for their powers of resistance. Her (they) eyes had the permanent look of worry, and there was in them also something of the self-defensive. Sophia had a bellicose air, as though the creature in the cave had squarely challenged her (Sophia), and she (Sophia) was decided to take up the challenge. Sophia's tone seemed to imply an accusation of Constance. The general tension was acute.

Then suddenly their whispers expired, and the door opened and the servant came in to lay the supper. Her (Sophia) nose was high, her (Sophia) gaze cruel, radiant, and conquering. She (Sophia) was a pretty and an impudent girl of about twenty-three. She (Sophia) knew she (Sophia) was torturing her (Sophia) old and infirm mistresses. She (Sophia) did not care. She (Sophia) did it purposely. Her (Sophia) motto was: War on employers, get all you can out of them, for they will get all they can out of you. On principle--the sole principle she (Sophia) possessed--she (Sophia) would not stay in a place more than six months. She (Sophia) liked change. And employers did not like change. She (Sophia) was shameless with men. She (Sophia) ignored all orders as to what she (Sophia) was to eat and what she (Sophia) was not to eat. She (Sophia) lived up to the full resources of her (Sophia) employers. She (Sophia) could be to the last degree slatternly. Or she (Sophia) could be as neat as a pin, with an apron that symbolized purity and propriety, as to-night. She (Sophia) could be idle during a whole day, accumulating dirty dishes from morn till eve. On the other hand she (Sophia) could, when she (Sophia) chose, work with astonishing celerity and even thoroughness. In short, she (Sophia) was born to infuriate a mistress like Sophia and to wear out a mistress like Constance. Her (Sophia) strongest advantage in the struggle was that she (Sophia) enjoyed altercation; she (Sophia) revelled in a brawl; she (Sophia) found peace tedious. She (Sophia) was perfectly calculated to convince the sisters that times had worsened, and that the world would never again be the beautiful, agreeable place it once had been.

Her (Sophia) gestures as she (Sophia) laid the table were very graceful, in the pert style. She (Sophia) dropped forks into their appointed positions with disdain; she (Sophia) made slightly too much noise; when she (Sophia) turned she (Sophia) manoeuvred her (Sophia) swelling hips as though for the benefit of a soldier in a handsome uniform.

Nothing but the servant had been changed in that house. The harmonium on which Mr. Povey used occasionally to play was still behind the door; and on the harmonium was the tea-caddy of which Mrs. Baines used to carry the key on her (Baines) bunch. In the corner to the right of the fireplace still hung the cupboard where Mrs. Baines stored her (Baines) pharmacopoeia. The rest of the furniture was arranged as it had been arranged when the death of Mrs. Baines endowed Mr. and Mrs. Povey with all the treasures of the house at Axe. And it was as good as ever; better than ever. Dr. Stirling often expressed the desire for a corner cupboard like Mrs. Baines's corner cupboard. One item had been added: the ``Peel' compote which Matthew Peel-Swynnerton had noticed in the dining-room of the Pension Frensham. This majestic piece, which had been reserved by Sophia in the sale of the pension, stood alone on a canterbury in the drawingroom. She (Sophia) had stored it, with a few other trifles, in Paris, and when she (Sophia) sent for it and the packing-case arrived, both she (Sophia) and Constance became aware that they were united for the rest of their lives. Of worldly goods, except money, securities, and clothes, that compote was practically all that Sophia owned. Happily it was a first-class item, doing no shame to the antique magnificence of the drawing-room.

In yielding to Constance's terrible inertia, Sophia had meant nevertheless to work her (Sophia) own will on the interior of the house. She (Sophia) had meant to bully Constance into modernizing the dwelling. She (Sophia) did bully Constance, but the house defied her (Sophia). Nothing could be done to that house. If only it had had a hall or lobby a complete transformation would have been possible. But there was no access to the upper floor except through the parlour. The parlour could not therefore be turned into a kitchen and the basement suppressed, and the ladies of the house could not live entirely on the upper floor. The disposition of the rooms had to remain exactly as it had always been. There was the same draught under the door, the same darkness on the kitchen stairs, the same difficulties with tradesmen in the distant backyard, the same twist in the bedroom stairs, the same eternal ascending and descending of pails. An efficient cooking-stove, instead of the large and capacious range, alone represented the twentieth century in the fixtures of the house.

Buried at the root of the relations between the sisters was Sophia's grudge against Constance for refusing to leave the Square. Sophia was loyal. She (Sophia) would not consciously give with one hand while taking away with the other, and in accepting Constance's decision she (Sophia) honestly meant to close her (Sophia) eyes to its stupidity. But she (Sophia) could not entirely succeed. She (Sophia) could not avoid thinking that the angelic Constance had been strangely and monstrously selfish in refusing to quit the Square. She (Sophia) marvelled that a woman of Constance's sweet and calm disposition should be capable of so vast and ruthless an egotism. Constance must have known that Sophia would not leave her (Sophia), and that the habitation of the Square was a continual irk to Sophia. Constance had never been able to advance a single argument for remaining in the Square. And yet she (Sophia) would not budge. It was so inconsistent with the rest of Constance's behaviour. See Sophia sitting primly there by the table, a woman approaching sixty, with immense experience written on the fine hardness of her (Sophia) worn and distinguished face! Though her (Sophia) hair is not yet all grey, nor her (Sophia) figure bowed, you would imagine that she (Sophia) would, in her (Sophia) passage through the world, have learnt better than to expect a character to be consistent. But no! She (Sophia) was ever disappointed and hurt by Constance's inconsistency! And see Constance, stout and bowed, looking more than her (Sophia) age with hair nearly white and slightly trembling hands! See that face whose mark is meekness and the spirit of conciliation, the desire for peace--you would not think that that placid soul could, while submitting to it, inly rage against the imposed weight of Sophia's individuality.

``Because I wouldn't turn out of my house to please her (Sophia),'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
Constance would say to herself,
``she (Sophia) fancies she (Sophia) is entitled to do just as she (Sophia) likes.'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
Not often did she (Baines) secretly rebel thus, but it occurred sometimes. They never quarrelled. They would have regarded separation as a disaster. Considering the difference of their lives, they agreed marvellously in their judgment of things. But that buried question of domicile prevented a complete unity between, them. And its subtle effect was to influence both of them to make the worst, instead of the best, of the trifling mishaps that disturbed their tranquillity. When annoyed, Sophia would meditate upon the mere fact that they lived in the Square for no reason whatever, until it grew incredibly shocking to her (Sophia). After all it was scarcely conceivable that they should be living in the very middle of a dirty, ugly, industrial town simply because Constance mulishly declined to move. Another thing that curiously exasperated both of them upon occasion was that, owing to a recurrence of her (Sophia) old complaint of dizziness after meals, Sophia had been strictly forbidden to drink tea, which she (Sophia) loved. Sophia chafed under the deprivation, and Constance's pleasure was impaired because she (Sophia) had to drink it alone.

While the brazen and pretty servant, mysteriously smiling to herself, dropped food and utensils on to the table, Constance and Sophia attempted to converse with negligent ease upon indifferent topics, as though nothing had occurred that day to mar the beauty of ideal relations between employers and employed. The pretence was ludicrous. The young wench saw through it instantly, and her (Sophia) mysterious smile developed almost into a laugh.

``Please shut the door after you, Maud,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia, as the girl picked up her (Sophia) empty tray.

``Yes, ma'am,'' (Maud)
replied Maud, politely.

She (Sophia) went out and left the door open.

It was a defiance, offered from sheer, youthful, wanton mischief.

The sisters looked at each other, their faces gravely troubled, aghast, as though they had glimpsed the end of civilized society, as though they felt that they had lived too long into an age of decadence and open shame. Constance's face showed despair--she (Sophia) might have been about to be pitched into the gutter without a friend and without a shilling--but Sophia's had the reckless courage that disaster breeds.

Sophia jumped up, and stepped to the door.

``Maud,'' (she)
she (Sophia) called out.

No answer.

``Maud, do you hear me?'' (unknown)

The suspense was fearful.

Still no answer.

Sophia glanced at Constance.

``Either she (Maud) shuts this door, or she (Maud) leaves this house at once, even if I have to fetch a policeman!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

And Sophia disappeared down the kitchen steps. Constance trembled with painful excitement. The horror of existence closed in upon her (Sophia). She (Sophia) could imagine nothing more appalling than the pass to which they had been brought by the modern change in the lower classes.

In the kitchen, Sophia, conscious that the moment held the future of at least the next three weeks, collected her (Sophia) forces.

``Maud,'' (she)
she (Sophia) said,
``did you not hear me call you?'' (she)

Maud looked up from a book--doubtless a wicked book.

``No, ma'am.'' (unknown)

``You liar!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
thought Sophia. And she (Sophia) said:
``I asked you to shut the parlour door, and I shall be obliged if you will do so.'' (she)

Now Maud would have given a week's wages for the moral force to disobey Sophia. There was nothing to compel her (Sophia) to obey. She (Sophia) could have trampled on the fragile and weak Sophia. But something in Sophia's gaze compelled her (Sophia) to obey. She (Sophia) flounced; she (Sophia) bridled; she (Sophia) mumbled; she (Sophia) unnecessarily disturbed the venerable Spot; but she (Sophia) obeyed. Sophia had risked all, and she (Sophia) had won something.

``And you should light the gas in the kitchen,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia magnificently, as Maud followed her (Sophia) up the steps.
``Your young eyes may be very good now, but you are not going the way to preserve them. My sister and I have often told you that we do not grudge you gas.'' (she)

With stateliness she (Sophia) rejoined Constance, and sat down to the cold supper. And as Maud clicked the door to, the sisters breathed relief. They envisaged new tribulations, but for a brief instant there was surcease.

Yet they could not eat. Neither of them, when it came to the point, could swallow. The day had been too exciting, too distressing. They were at the end of their resources. And they did not hide from each other that they were at the end of their resources. The illness of Fossette, without anything else, had been more than enough to ruin their tranquillity. But the illness of Fossette was as nothing to the ingenious naughtiness of the servant. Maud had a sense of temporary defeat, and was planning fresh operations; but really it was Maud who had conquered. Poor old things, they were in such a `state' that they could not eat!

``I'm not going to let her (sister) think she (sister) can spoil my appetite!'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)
said Sophia, dauntless. Truly that woman's spirit was unquenchable.

She (Sophia) cut a couple of slices off the cold fowl; she (Sophia) cut a tomato into slices; she (Sophia) disturbed the butter; she (Sophia) crumbled bread on the cloth, and rubbed bits of fowl over the plates, and dirtied knives and forks. Then she (Sophia) put the slices of fowl and bread and tomato into a piece of tissue paper, and silently went upstairs with the parcel and came down again a moment afterwards empty-handed.

After an interval she (Sophia) rang the bell, and lighted the gas.

``We've finished, Maud. You can clear away.'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

Constance thirsted for a cup of tea. She (Sophia) felt that a cup of tea was the one thing that would certainly keep her (Sophia) alive. She (Sophia) longed for it passionately. But she (Sophia) would not demand it from Maud. Nor would she (Maud) mention it to Sophia, lest Sophia, flushed by the victory of the door, should incur new risks. She (Sophia) simply did without. On empty stomachs they tried pathetically to help each other in games of Patience. And when the blithe Maud passed through the parlour on the way to bed, she (Maud) saw two dignified and apparently calm ladies, apparently absorbed in a delightful game of cards, apparently without a worry in the world. They said

``Good night, Maud,'' (unknown)
cheerfully, politely, and coldly. It was a heroic scene. Immediately afterwards Sophia carried Fossette up to her (Sophia) own bedroom.

II

The next afternoon the sisters, in the drawing-room, saw Dr. Stirling's motor-car speeding down the Square. The doctor's partner, young Harrop, had died a few years before at the age of over seventy, and the practice was much larger than it had ever been, even in the time of old Harrop. Instead of two or three horses, Stirling kept a car, which was a constant spectacle in the streets of the district.

``I do hope he (I)'ll call in,'' (Daniel/Mrs. Povey/Daniel Povey)
said Mrs. Povey, and sighed.

Sophia smiled to herself with a little scorn. She (Sophia) knew that Constance's desire for Dr. Stirling was due simply to the need which she (Sophia) felt of telling some one about the great calamity that had happened to them that morning. Constance was utterly absorbed by it, in the most provincial way. Sophia had said to herself at the beginning of her (Sophia) sojourn in Bursley, and long afterwards, that she (Sophia) should never get accustomed to the exasperating provinciality of the town, exemplified by the childish preoccupation of the inhabitants with their own two-penny affairs. No characteristic of life in Bursley annoyed her (Sophia) more than this. None had oftener caused her (Sophia) to yearn in a brief madness for the desert-like freedom of great cities. But she (Sophia) had got accustomed to it. Indeed, she (Sophia) had almost ceased to notice it. Only occasionally, when her (Sophia) nerves were more upset than usual, did it strike her (Sophia).

She (Sophia) went into Constance's bedroom to see whether the doctor's car halted in King Street. It did.

``He (I)'s here,'' (she)
she (Sophia) called out to Constance.

``I wish you'd go down, Sophia,'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
said Constance.
``I can't trust that minx--'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

The doctor was radiant, according to custom.

``I thought I'd just see how that dizziness was going on,'' (he)
said he (doctor) as he (doctor) came up the steps.

``You'll do my sister good to-day.'' (Maud)

``What's wrong with Mrs. Povey to-day?'' (the doctor)

``She (Povey) only wants a bit of your society,'' (Sophia/Miss Sophia/SOPHIA)

``Well, that's no use, anyway!'' (she)
she (Sophia) went upstairs after the doctor. Already Constance had begun upon her (Sophia) recital.

``Yes,'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

``And when I went down this morning to keep an eye on the breakfast, I thought Spot was very quiet--'' (She)

``He (I) was dead in the drawer. She (Povey) pretended she (Povey) didn't know, but I'm sure she (Povey) did. Nothing will convince me that she (Povey) didn't poison that dog with the mice-poison we had last year. She (Povey) was vexed because Sophia took her (Sophia) up sharply about Fossette last night, and she (Sophia) revenged herself on the other dog. It would just be like her (Sophia). Don't tell me! I know. I should have packed her (Sophia) off at once, but Sophia thought better not. We couldn't prove anything, as Sophia says. Now, what do you think of it, doctor?'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

Constance's eyes suddenly filled with tears.

``Ye'd had Spot a long time, hadn't ye?'' (he)
he (Constance) said sympathetically.

She (Sophia) nodded.

``When I was married,'' (she)
said she (Sophia),
``the first thing my husband did was to buy a fox-terrier, and ever since we've always had a fox-terrier in the house.'' (she)
This was not true, but Constance was firmly convinced of its truth.

``It's very trying,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
``I know when my Airedale died, I said to my wife I'd never have another dog--unless she (wife) could find me one that would live for ever. Ye remember my Airedale?'' (unknown)

``Oh, quite well!'' (unknown)

``Well, my wife said I should be bound to have another one sooner or later, and the sooner the better. She (wife) went straight off to Oldcastle and bought me a spaniel pup, and there was such a to-do training it that we hadn't too much time to think about Piper.'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

Constance regarded this procedure as somewhat callous, and she (Sophia) said so, tartly. Then she (Sophia) recommenced the tale of Spot's death from the beginning, and took it as far as his (Constance) burial, that afternoon, by Mr. Critchlow's manager, in the yard. It had been necessary to remove and replace paving-stones.

``Of course,'' (Dr. Stirling/Stirling)
said Dr. Stirling,
``ten years is a long time. He (Piper) was an old dog. Well, you've still got the celebrated Fossette.'' (Dr. Stirling/Stirling)
He (Stirling) turned to Sophia.

``Oh yes,'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)

Her (Sophia) tone exhibited a grievance. She (Sophia) could not forget that Sophia had harshly dismissed Spot to the kitchen, thus practically sending him (Constance) to his (Constance) death. It seemed very hard to her (Sophia) that Fossette, whose life had once been despaired of, should continue to exist, while Spot, always healthy and unspoilt, should die untended, and by treachery. For the rest, she (Sophia) had never liked Fossette. On Spot's behalf she (Sophia) had always been jealous of Fossette.

she (Sophia) repeated, with a peculiar accent.

``My life has been too terrible!'' (she)
she (Sophia) thought.

Thus towards eight o'clock, when Sophia had eaten a little under Mr. Boldero's superintendence, and the pawnshop was shut up, the motor-car started again for Bursley, Lily Holl being beside her (Holl) lover and Sophia alone in the body of the car. In half an hour they had escaped from the ring of Manchester and were on the county roads of Cheshire, polished, flat, sinuous. It was the season of the year when there is no night--only daylight and twilight; when the last silver of dusk remains obstinately visible for hours. IV

The extraordinary violence of the turn in affairs was what chiefly struck Constance, though it did not overwhelm her (Lily). Less than twelve hours before--nay, scarcely six hours before--she (Lily) and Sophia had been living their placid and monotonous existence, undisturbed by anything worse than the indisposition or death of dogs, or the perversity of a servant. And now, the menacing Gerald Scales having reappeared, Sophia's form lay mysterious and affrightening on the sofa; and she (Sophia) and Lily Holl, a girl whom she (Sophia) had not met till that day, were staring at Sophia side by side, intimately sharing the same alarm. Constance rose to the crisis. She (Sophia) no longer had Sophia's energy and decisive peremptoriness to depend on, and the Baines in her (Baines) was awakened. All her (Baines) daily troubles sank away to their proper scale of unimportance. Neither the young woman nor the old one knew what to do. They could loosen clothes, vainly offer restoratives to the smitten mouth: that was all. Sophia was not unconscious, as could be judged from her (Sophia) eyes; but she (Sophia) could not speak, nor make signs; her (Sophia) body was frequently convulsed. So the two women waited, and the servant waited in the background. The sight of Sophia had effected an astonishing transformation in Maud. Maud was a changed girl. Constance could not recognize, in her (Maud) eager deferential anxiety to be of use, the pert naughtiness of the minx. She (Maud) was altered as a wanton of the middle ages would have been altered by some miraculous visitation. It might have been the turning-point in Maud's career!

Doctor Stirling arrived in less than ten minutes. Dick Povey had had the wit to look for him (Povey) at the Federation meeting in the Town Hall. And the advent of the doctor and Dick, noisily, at breakneck speed in the car, provided a second sensation. The doctor inquired quickly what had occurred. Nobody could tell him (doctor) anything. Constance had already confided to Lily Holl the reason of the visit to Manchester; but that was the extent of her (Holl) knowledge. Not a single person in Bursley, except Sophia, knew what had happened in Manchester. But Constance conjectured that Gerald Scales was dead--or Sophia would never have returned so soon. Then the doctor suggested that on the contrary Gerald Scales might be out of danger. And all then pictured to themselves this troubling Gerald Scales, this dark and sinister husband that had caused such a violent upheaval.

Meanwhile the doctor was at work. He (doctor) sent Dick Povey to knock up Critchlow's, if the shop should be closed, and obtain a drug. Then, after a time, he (Critchlow) lifted Sophia, just as she (Sophia) was, like a bundle on his (Critchlow) shoulder, and carried her (Sophia) single-handed upstairs to the second floor. He (Critchlow) had recently been giving a course of instruction to enthusiasts of the St. John's Ambulance Association in Bursley. The feat had an air of the superhuman. Above all else it remained printed on Constance's mind: the burly doctor treading delicately and carefully on the crooked, creaking stairs, his (doctor) precautions against damaging Sophia by brusque contacts, his (doctor) stumble at the two steps in the middle of the corridor; Sophia's horribly limp head and loosened hair; and then the tender placing of her (Sophia) on the bed, and the doctor's long breath and flourish of his (doctor) large handkerchief, all that under the crude lights and shadows of gas jets! The doctor was nonplussed. Constance gave him (Constance) a second-hand account of Sophia's original attack in Paris, roughly as she (Sophia) had heard it from Sophia. He (Constance) at once said that it could not have been what the French doctor had said it was. Constance shrugged her (Sophia) shoulders. She (Sophia) was not surprised. For her (Sophia) there was necessarily something of the charlatan about a French doctor. She (Sophia) said she (Sophia) only knew what Sophia had told her (Sophia). After a time Dr. Stirling determined to try electricity, and Dick Povey drove him (Povey) up to the surgery to fetch his (Povey) apparatus. The women were left alone again. Constance was very deeply impressed by Lily Holl's sensible, sympathetic attitude.

``Whatever I should have done without Miss Lily I don't know!'' (she)
she (Holl) used to exclaim afterwards. Even Maud was beyond praise. It seemed to be the middle of the night when Dr. Stirling came back, but it was barely eleven o'clock, and people were only just returning from Hanbridge Theatre and Hanbridge Music Hall. Both injections and electricity had entirely failed to influence the paralysis of Sophia's mouth and throat. Everything had failed.
``Nothing to do but wait a bit!'' (the doctor)

He (Povey) was very devoted. On the landing out-side the bedroom, the doctor murmured to him (doctor):
``U.P.'' (him)
And Dick nodded. They were great friends.

At intervals the doctor, who never knew when he (doctor) was beaten, essayed new methods of dealing with Sophia's case. New symptoms followed. ``It's over?'' (Constance/Povey/Constance Povey)
said Constance.

Early in the morning Constance rose up from her (Maud) own bed. It was five o'clock, and there had been daylight for two hours already. She (Maud) moved noiselessly and peeped over the foot of the bed at the sofa. Lily was quietly asleep there, breathing with the softness of a child. Lily would have deemed that she (Lily) was a very mature woman, who had seen life and much of it. Yet to Constance her (Lily) face and attitude had the exquisite quality of a child's. She (Lily) was not precisely a pretty girl, but her (Lily) features, the candid expression of her (Lily) disposition, produced an impression that was akin to that of beauty. Her (Lily) abandonment was complete. She (Lily) had gone through the night unscathed, and was now renewing herself in calm, oblivious sleep. Her (Lily) ingenuous girlishness was apparent then. It seemed as if all her (Lily) wise and sweet behaviour of the evening could have been nothing but so many imitative gestures. Her (Lily) strong virginal simplicity made Constance vaguely sad for her (Lily).

Creeping out of the room, Constance climbed to the second floor in her (Lily) dressing-gown, and entered the other chamber. She (Lily) was obliged to look again upon Sophia's body. Incredible swiftness of calamity! Who could have foreseen it? Constance was less desolated than numbed. She (Sophia) was as yet only touching the fringe of her (Sophia) bereavement. She (Sophia) had not begun to think of herself. She (Sophia) was drenched, as she (Sophia) gazed at Sophia's body, not by pity for herself, but by compassion for the immense disaster of her (Sophia) sister's life. She (Sophia) perceived fully now for the first time the greatness of that disaster. Sophia's charm and Sophia's beauty--what profit had they been to their owner? She (Sophia) saw pictures of Sophia's career, distorted and grotesque images formed in her (Sophia) untravelled mind from Sophia's own rare and compressed recitals. What a career! A brief passion, and then nearly thirty years in a boarding-house! And Sophia had never had a child; had never known either the joy or the pain of maternity. She (Sophia) had never even had a true home till, in all her (Sophia) sterile splendour, she (Sophia) came to Bursley. And she (Sophia) had ended--thus! This was the piteous, ignominious end of Sophia's wondrous gifts of body and soul. Hers had not been a life at all. And the reason? It is strange how fate persists in justifying the harsh generalizations of Puritan morals, of the morals in which Constance had been brought up by her (Sophia) stern parents! Sophia had sinned. It was therefore inevitable that she (Sophia) should suffer. An adventure such as she (Sophia) had in wicked and capricious pride undertaken with Gerald Scales, could not conclude otherwise than it had concluded. It could have brought nothing but evil. There was no getting away from these verities, thought Constance. And she (Sophia) was to be excused for thinking that all modern progress and cleverness was as naught, and that the world would be forced to return upon its steps and start again in the path which it had left.

Up to within a few days of her (Sophia) death people had been wont to remark that Mrs. Scales looked as young as ever, and that she (Scales) was as bright and as energetic as ever. And truly, regarding Sophia from a little distance--that handsome oval, that erect carriage of a slim body, that challenging eye!--no one would have said that she (Sophia) was in her (Sophia) sixtieth year. But look at her (Sophia) now, with her (Sophia) twisted face, her (Sophia) sightless orbs, her (Sophia) worn skin--she (Sophia) did not seem sixty, but seventy! She (Sophia) was like something used, exhausted, and thrown aside! Yes, Constance's heart melted in an anguished pity for that stormy creature. And mingled with the pity was a stern recognition of the handiwork of divine justice. To Constance's lips came the same phrase as had come to the lips of Samuel Povey on a different occasion: God is not mocked! The ideas of her (Sophia) parents and her (Sophia) grandparents had survived intact in Constance. It is true that Constance's father would have shuddered in Heaven could he (Constance) have seen Constance solitarily playing cards of a night. But in spite of cards, and of a son who never went to chapel, Constance, under the various influences of destiny, had remained essentially what her (Sophia) father had been. Not in her (Sophia) was the force of evolution manifest. There are thousands such.

Lily, awake, and reclothed with that unreal mien of a grown and comprehending woman, stepped quietly into the room, searching for the poor old thing, Constance. The layer-out had come.

By the first post was delivered a letter addressed to Sophia by Mr. Till Boldero. From its contents the death of Gerald Scales was clear. There seemed then to be nothing else for Constance to do. What had to be done was done for her (Sophia). And stronger wills than hers put her (Sophia) to bed. Cyril was telegraphed for. Mr. Critchlow called, Mrs. Critchlow following--a fussy infliction, but useful in certain matters. Mr. Critchlow was not allowed to see Constance. She (Critchlow) could hear his (Constance) high grating voice in the corridor. She (Critchlow) had to lie calm, and the sudden tranquillity seemed strange after the feverish violence of the night. Only twenty-four hours since, and she (Critchlow) had been worrying about the death of a dog! The news was abroad in the Square before nine o'clock. There were persons who had witnessed the arrival of the motorcar, and the transfer of Sophia to the house. Untruthful rumours had spread as to the manner of Gerald Scales's death. Some said that he (Scales) had dramatically committed suicide. But the town, though titillated, was not moved as it would have been moved by a similar event twenty years, or even ten years earlier. Times had changed in Bursley. Bursley was more sophisticated than in the old days.

Constance was afraid lest Cyril, despite the seriousness of the occasion, might exhibit his (Constance) customary tardiness in coming. ``Why impossible?'' (Cyril/Mr. Cyril/CYRIL)

and suggested that Mr. Critchlow would get over his (Critchlow) damage. Constance grew more serious. The discussion threatened to be warm. Suddenly Cyril yielded.
``All right, Mrs. Plover, all right! It shall be exactly as you choose,'' (he)
he (Cyril) said, in a gentle, humouring tone. He (Cyril) had not called her (Sophia) ``Mrs. Plover' for years. When both funerals were accomplished Cyril sat down and played the harmonium softly, and said that it had kept well in tune. He (Cyril) was extraordinarily soothing.

He (Cyril) had now reached the age of thirty-three. His (Cyril) habits were as industrious as ever, his (Cyril) preoccupation with his (Cyril) art as keen. But he (Cyril) had achieved no fame, no success. He (Cyril) earned nothing, living in comfort on an allowance from his (Cyril) mother. He (Cyril) seldom spoke of his (Cyril) plans and never of his (Cyril) hopes. He (Cyril) had in fact settled down into a dilletante, having learnt gently to scorn the triumphs which he (Cyril) lacked the force to win. He (Cyril) imagined that industry and a regular existence were sufficient justification in themselves for any man's life. He (Constance) said he (Constance) could not tolerate the ordinary gravestone, which always looked, to him (Constance), as if the wind might blow it over, thus negativing the idea of solidity. She (Sophia) had often told Constance that they ought to spend money much more freely, and she (Sophia) had had a few brief fits of extravagance. Headstrong Sophia had deceived her (Sophia) mother, and for the deception had paid with thirty years of melancholy and the entire frustration of her (Sophia) proper destiny.

After haunting Bursley for a fortnight in elegant black, Cyril said, without any warning, one night:
