II

When, in the evening, after all sorts of comings and goings, he (Constance) finally returned to the old lady and the young one, in order to report the upshot, his (Constance) demeanour was suitably toned to Constance's mood. The old lady had been very deeply disturbed by the tragedy, which, as she (lady) said, had passed under her (lady) very feet while she (lady) was calmly talking to Lily.

The whole truth came out in a short space of time. Mrs. Critchlow was suffering from melancholia. It appeared that for long she (Critchlow) had been depressed by the failing trade of the shop, which was none of her (Critchlow) fault. The state of the Square had steadily deteriorated. Even the ``Vaults' were not what they once were. Four or five shops had been shut up, as it were definitely, the landlords having given up hope of discovering serious tenants. And, of those kept open, the majority were struggling desperately to make ends meet. Only Holl's and a new upstart draper, who had widely advertised his (draper) dress-making department, were really flourishing. The confectionery half of Mr. Brindley's business was disappearing. People would not go to Hanbridge for their bread or for their groceries, but they would go for their cakes. These electric trams had simply carried to Hanbridge the cream, and much of the milk, of Bursley's retail trade. There were unprincipled tradesmen in Hanbridge ready to pay the car-fares of any customer who spent a crown in their establishments. Hanbridge was the geographical centre of the Five Towns, and it was alive to its situation. Useless for Bursley to compete! If Mrs. Critchlow had been a philosopher, if she (Critchlow) had known that geography had always made history, she (Critchlow) would have given up her (Critchlow) enterprise a dozen years ago. But Mrs. Critchlow was merely Maria Insull. She (Critchlow) had seen Baines's in its magnificent prime, when Baines's almost conferred a favour on customers in serving them. At the time when she (Baines) took over the business under the wing of her (Baines) husband, it was still a good business. But from that instant the tide had seemed to turn. She (Baines) had fought, and she (Baines) kept on fighting, stupidly. She (Baines) was not aware that she (Baines) was fighting against evolution, not aware that evolution had chosen her (Baines) for one of its victims! She (Baines) could understand that all the other shops in the Square should fail, but not that Baines's should fail! She (Baines) was as industrious as ever, as good a buyer, as good a seller, as keen for novelties, as economical, as methodical! And yet the returns dropped and dropped.

She (Baines) naturally had no sympathy from Charles, who now took small interest even in his (Charles) own business, or what was left of it, and who was coldly disgusted at the ultimate cost of his (Charles) marriage. Charles gave her (Baines) no money that he (Charles) could avoid giving her (Baines). The crisis had been slowly approaching for years. The assistants in the shop had said nothing, or had only whispered among themselves, but now that the crisis had flowered suddenly in an attempted self-murder, they all spoke at once, and the evidences were pieced together into a formidable proof of the strain which Mrs. Critchlow had suffered. It appeared that for many months she (Critchlow) had been depressed and irritable, that sometimes she (Critchlow) would sit down in the midst of work and declare, with every sign of exhaustion, that she (Critchlow) could do no more. Then with equal briskness she (Critchlow) would arise and force herself to labour. She (Critchlow) did not sleep for whole nights. One assistant related how she (Critchlow) had complained of having had no sleep whatever for four nights consecutively. She (Critchlow) had noises in the ears and a chronic headache. Never very plump, she (Critchlow) had grown thinner and thinner. And she (Critchlow) was for ever taking pills: this information came from Charles's manager. She (Critchlow) had had several outrageous quarrels with the redoubtable Charles, to the stupefaction of all who heard or saw them... Mrs. Critchlow standing up to her (Critchlow) husband! Another strange thing was that she (Critchlow) thought the bills of several of the big Manchester firms were unpaid, when as a fact they had been paid. Even when shown the receipts she (Critchlow) would not be convinced, though she (Critchlow) pretended to be convinced. She (Critchlow) would recommence the next day. All this was sufficiently disconcerting for female assistants in the drapery. But what could they do?

Then Maria Critchlow had gone a step further. She (Critchlow) had summoned the eldest assistant to her (Critchlow) corner and had informed her (Critchlow), with all the solemnity of a confession made to assuage a conscience which has been tortured too long, that she (Critchlow) had on many occasions been guilty of sexual irregularity with her (Critchlow) late employer, Samuel Povey. There was no truth whatever in this accusation -LRB-which everybody, however, took care not to mention to Constance-RRB-; it merely indicated, perhaps, the secret aspirations of Maria Insull, the virgin. The assistant was properly scandalized, more by the crudity of Mrs. Critchlow's language than by the alleged sin buried in the past. Goodness knows what the assistant would have done! But two hours later Maria Critchlow tried to commit suicide by stabbing herself with a pair of scissors. There was blood in the shop.

With as little delay as possible she (Critchlow) had been driven away to the asylum. Charles Critchlow, enveloped safely in the armour of his (Critchlow) senile egotism, had shown no emotion, and very little activity. The shop was closed. And as a general draper's it never opened again. That was the end of Baines's. Two assistants found themselves without a livelihood. The small tumble with the great.

Constance's emotion was more than pardonable; it was justified. She (Baines) could not eat and Lily could not persuade her (Lily) to eat. In an unhappy moment Dick Povey mentioned--he (Povey) never could remember how, afterwards--the word Federation! And then Constance, from a passive figure of grief became a menace. She (Lily) overwhelmed Dick Povey with her (Lily) anathema of Federation, for Dick was a citizen of Hanbridge, where this detestable movement for Federation had had its birth. All the misfortunes of St. Luke's Square were due to that great, busy, grasping, unscrupulous neighbour. Had not Hanbridge done enough, without wanting to merge all the Five Towns into one town, of which of course itself would be the centre? For Constance, Hanbridge was a borough of unprincipled adventurers, bent on ruining the ancient ``Mother of the Five Towns' for its own glory and aggrandizement. Let Constance hear no more of Federation! Her (Mother) poor sister Sophia had been dead against Federation, and she (Sophia) had been quite right! All really respectable people were against it! The attempted suicide of Mrs. Critchlow sealed the fate of Federation and damned it for ever, in Constance's mind. Her (Critchlow) hatred of the idea of it was intensified into violent animosity; insomuch that in the result she (Critchlow) died a martyr to the cause of Bursley's municipal independence.

III

It was on a muddy day in October that the first great battle for and against Federation was fought in Bursley. Constance was suffering severely from sciatica. She (Critchlow) was also suffering from disgust with the modern world.

Unimaginable things had happened in the Square. For Constance, the reputation of the Square was eternally ruined. Charles Critchlow, by that strange good fortune which always put him (Critchlow) in the right when fairly he (Critchlow) ought to have been in the wrong, had let the Baines shop and his (Critchlow) own shop and house to the Midland Clothiers Company, which was establishing branches throughout Staffordshire, Warwickshire, Leicestershire, and adjacent counties. He (Critchlow) had sold his (Critchlow) own chemist's stock and gone to live in a little house at the bottom of Kingstreet. It is doubtful whether he (Critchlow) would have consented to retire had not Alderman Holl died earlier in the year, thus ending a long rivalry between the old men for the patriarchate of the Square. Charles Critchlow was as free from sentiment as any man, but no man is quite free from it, and the ancient was in a position to indulge sentiment had he (man) chosen. His (man) business was not a source of loss, and he (man) could still trust his (man) skinny hands and peering eyes to make up a prescription. However, the offer of the Midland Clothiers Company tempted him (man), and as the undisputed `father' of the Square he (father) left the Square in triumph.

The Midland Clothiers Company had no sense of the proprieties of trade. Their sole idea was to sell goods. Having possessed themselves of one of the finest sites in a town which, after all was said and done, comprised nearly forty thousand inhabitants, they set about to make the best of that site. They threw the two shops into one, and they caused to be constructed a sign compared to which the spacious old ``Baines' sign was a postcard. They covered the entire frontage with posters of a theatrical description--coloured posters! They occupied the front page of the Signal, and from that pulpit they announced that winter was approaching, and that they meant to sell ten thousand overcoats at their new shop in Bursley at the price of twelve and sixpence each. The tailoring of the world was loudly and coarsely defied to equal the value of those overcoats. On the day of opening they arranged an orchestra or artillery of phonographs upon the leads over the window of that part of the shop which had been Mr. Critchlow's. They also carpeted the Square with handbills, and flew flags from their upper storeys. The immense shop proved to be full of overcoats; overcoats were shown in all the three great windows; in one window an overcoat was disposed as a receptacle for water, to prove that the Midland twelve-and-sixpenny overcoats were impermeable by rain. Overcoats flapped in the two doorways. These devices woke and drew the town, and the town found itself received by bustling male assistants very energetic and rapid, instead of by demure anaemic virgins. At moments towards evening the shop was populous with custom; the number of overcoats sold was prodigious. On another day the Midland sold trousers in a like manner, but without the phonographs. Unmistakably the Midland had shaken the Square and demonstrated that commerce was still possible to fearless enterprise.

Nevertheless the Square was not pleased. The Square was conscious of shame, of dignity departed. Constance was divided between pain and scornful wrath. For her (assistants), what the Midland had done was to desecrate a shrine. She (assistants) hated those flags, and those flaring, staring posters on the honest old brick walls, and the enormous gilded sign, and the windows all filled with a monotonous repetition of the same article, and the bustling assistants. As for the phonographs, she (assistants) regarded them as a grave insult; they had been within twenty feet of her (assistants) drawing-room window! Twelve-and-sixpenny overcoats! It was monstrous, and equally monstrous was the gullibility of the people. How could an overcoat at twelve and sixpence be

``good.'' (She)
She (Critchlow) remembered the overcoats made and sold in the shop in the time of her (Critchlow) father and her (Critchlow) husband, overcoats of which the inconvenience was that they would not wear out! The Midland, for Constance, was not a trading concern, but something between a cheap-jack and a circus. She (Critchlow) could scarcely bear to walk down the Square, to such a degree did the ignoble frontage of the Midland offend her (Critchlow) eye and outrage her (Critchlow) ancestral pride. She (Critchlow) even said that she (Critchlow) would give up her (Critchlow) house.

But when, on the twenty-ninth of September, she (Critchlow) received six months' notice, signed in Critchlow's shaky hand, to quit the house--it was wanted for the Midland's manager, the Midland having taken the premises on condition that they might eject Constance if they chose--the blow was an exceedingly severe one. She (Critchlow) had sworn to go--but to be turned out, to be turned out of the house of her (Critchlow) birth and out of her (Critchlow) father's home, that was different! Her (Critchlow) pride, injured as it was, had a great deal to support. It became necessary for her (Critchlow) to recollect that she (Critchlow) was a Baines. She (Critchlow) affected magnificently not to care. But she (Critchlow) could not refrain from telling all her (Critchlow) acquaintances that she (Critchlow) was being turned out of her (Critchlow) house, and asking them what they thought of THAT; and when she (Critchlow) met Charles Critchlow in the street she (Critchlow) seared him (Critchlow) with the heat of her (Critchlow) resentment. The enterprise of finding a new house and moving into it loomed before her (Critchlow) gigantic, terrible, the idea of it was alone sufficient to make her (Critchlow) ill.

Meanwhile, in the matter of Federation, preparations for the pitched battle had been going forward, especially in the columns of the Signal, where the scribes of each one of the Five Towns had proved that all the other towns were in the clutch of unscrupulous gangs of self-seekers. After months of argument and recrimination, all the towns except Bursley were either favourable or indifferent to the prospect of becoming a part of the twelfth largest town in the United Kingdom. But in Bursley the opposition was strong, and the twelfth largest town in the United Kingdom could not spring into existence without the consent of Bursley. The United Kingdom itself was languidly interested in the possibility of suddenly being endowed with a new town of a quarter of a million inhabitants. The Five Towns were frequently mentioned in the London dailies, and London journalists would write such sentences as:

``The Five Towns, which are of course, as everybody knows, Hanbridge, Bursley, Knype, Longshaw, and Turnhill...'' (London journalists)
This was renown at last, for the most maligned district in the country! And then a Cabinet Minister had visited the Five Towns, and assisted at an official inquiry, and stated in his (Minister) hammering style that he (Minister) meant personally to do everything possible to accomplish the Federation of the Five Towns: an incautious remark, which infuriated, while it flattered, the opponents of Federation in Bursley. Constance, with many other sensitive persons, asked angrily what right a Cabinet Minister had to take sides in a purely local affair. But the partiality of the official world grew flagrant. The Mayor of Bursley openly proclaimed himself a Federationist, though there was a majority on the Council against him (Mayor). Even ministers of religion permitted themselves to think and to express opinions. Well might the indignant Old Guard imagine that the end of public decency had come! The Federationists were very ingenious individuals. They contrived to enrol in their ranks a vast number of leading men. Then they hired the Covered Market, and put a platform in it, and put all these leading men on the platform, and made them all speak eloquently on the advantages of moving with the times. The meeting was crowded and enthusiastic, and readers of the Signal next day could not but see that the battle was won in advance, and that anti-Federation was dead. In the following week, however, the anti-Federationists held in the Covered Market an exactly similar meeting -LRB-except that the display of leading men was less brilliant-RRB-, and demanded of a floor of serried heads whether the old Mother of the Five Towns was prepared to put herself into the hands of a crew of highly-paid bureaucrats at Hanbridge, and was answered by a wild defiant
``No,'' (bureaucrats)
that could be heard on Duck Bank. Readers of the Signal next day were fain to see that the battle had not been won in advance. Bursley was lukewarm on the topics of education, slums, water, gas, electricity. But it meant to fight for that mysterious thing, its identity. Was the name of Bursley to be lost to the world? To ask the question was to give the answer.

Then dawned the day of battle, the day of the Poll, when the burgesses were to indicate plainly by means of a cross on a voting paper whether or not they wanted Federation. And on this day Constance was almost incapacitated by sciatica. It was a heroic day. The walls of the town were covered with literature, and the streets dotted with motor-cars and other vehicles at the service of the voters. The greater number of these vehicles bore large cards with the words,

``Federation this time.'' (hundreds)
And hundreds of men walked briskly about with circular cards tied to their lapels, as though Bursley had been a race-course, and these cards too had the words,
``Federation this time.'' (Bursley/Bursley Town Silver Prize Band)
-LRB-The reference was to a light poll which had been taken several years before, when no interest had been aroused and the immature project yet defeated by a six to one majority.-RRB- All partisans of Federation sported a red ribbon; all Anti-Federationists sported a blue ribbon. The schools were closed and the Federationists displayed their characteristic lack of scruple in appropriating the children. The Federationists, with devilish skill, had hired the Bursley Town Silver Prize Band, an organization of terrific respectability, and had set it to march playing through the town followed by wagonettes crammed with children, who sang:

Vote, vote, vote for Federation, Don't be stupid, old and slow, We are sure that it will be Good for the communitie, So vote, vote, vote, and make it go.

How this performance could affect the decision of grave burgesses at the polls was not apparent; but the Anti-Federationists feared that it might, and before noon was come they had engaged two bands and had composed in committee, the following lyric in reply to the first one:

Down, down, down, with Federation, As we are we'd rather stay; When the vote on Saturday's read Federation will be dead, Good old Bursley's sure to win the day.

They had also composed another song, entitled

``Dear old Bursley,'' (unknown)
which, however, they made the fatal error of setting to the music of
``Auld Lang Syne.'' (voters)
The effect was that of a dirge, and it perhaps influenced many voters in favour of the more cheerful party. The Anti-Federationists, indeed, never regained the mean advantage filched by unscrupulous Federationists with the help of the Silver Prize Band and a few hundred infants. The odds were against the Anti-Federationists. The mayor had actually issued a letter to the inhabitants accusing the Anti-Federationists of unfair methods! This was really too much! The impudence of it knocked the breath out of its victims, and breath is very necessary in a polling contest. The Federationists, as one of their prominent opponents admitted, `had it all their own way,'' dominating both the streets and the walls. And when, early in the afternoon, Mr. Dick Povey sailed over the town in a balloon that was plainly decorated with the crimson of Federation, it was felt that the cause of Bursley's separate identity was for ever lost. Still, Bursley, with the willing aid of the public-houses, maintained its gaiety.

IV

Towards dusk a stout old lady, with grey hair, and a dowdy bonnet, and an expensive mantle, passed limping, very slowly, along Wedgwood Street and up the Cock Yard towards the Town Hall. Her (lady) wrinkled face had an anxious look, but it was also very determined. The busy, joyous Federationists and Anti-Federationists who knew her (lady) not saw merely a stout old lady fussing forth, and those who knew her (lady) saw merely Mrs. Povey and greeted her (lady) perfunctorily, a woman of her (lady) age and gait being rather out of place in that feverish altercation of opposed principles. But it was more than a stout old lady, it was more than Mrs. Povey that waddled with such painful deliberation through the streets--it was a miracle.

In the morning Constance had been partially incapacitated by her (Povey) sciatica; so much so, at any rate, that she (Povey) had perceived the advisability of remaining on the bedroom floor instead of descending to the parlour. Therefore Mary had lighted the drawing-room fire, and Constance had ensconced herself by it, with Fossette in a basket. Lily Holl had called early, and had been very sympathetic, but rather vague. The truth was that she (Holl) was concealing the imminent balloon ascent which Dick Povey, with his (Povey) instinct for the picturesque, had somehow arranged, in conjunction with a well-known Manchester aeronaut, for the very day of the poll. That was one of various matters that had to be `kept from' the old lady. Lily herself was much perturbed about the balloon ascent. She (Lily) had to run off and see Dick before he (Dick) started, at the Football Ground at Bleakridge, and then she (Lily) had to live through the hours till she (Lily) should receive a telegram to the effect that Dick had come down safely or that Dick had broken his (Dick) leg in coming down, or that Dick was dead. It was a trying time for Lily. She (Lily) had left Constance after a brief visit, with a preoccupied unusual air, saying that as the day was a special day, she (Lily) should come in again `if she (Lily) could.

'' And she (Lily) did not forget to assure Constance that Federation would beyond any question whatever be handsomely beaten at the poll; for this was another matter as to which it was deemed advisable to keep the old lady `in the dark,'' (she)
lest the foolish old lady should worry and commit indiscretions.

After that Constance had been forgotten by the world of Bursley, which could pay small heed to sciatical old ladies confined to sofas and firesides. She (lady) was in acute pain, as Mary could see when at intervals she (Mary) hovered round her (Mary). Assuredly it was one of Constance's bad days, one of those days on which she (Mary) felt that the tide of life had left her (Mary) stranded in utter neglect. The sound of the Bursley Town Silver Prize Band aroused her (Mary) from her (Mary) mournful trance of suffering. Then the high treble of children's voices startled her (Mary). She (Mary) defied her (Mary) sciatica, and, grimacing, went to the window. And at the first glimpse she (Mary) could see that the Federation Poll was going to be a much more exciting affair than she (Mary) had imagined. The great cards swinging from the wagonettes showed her (Mary) that Federation was at all events still sufficiently alive to make a formidable impression on the eye and the ear. The Square was transformed by this clamour in favour of Federation; people cheered, and sang also, as the procession wound down the Square. And she (Mary) could distinctly catch the tramping, martial syllables,

``Vote, vote, vote.'' (she)
She (Mary) was indignant. The pother, once begun, continued. Vehicles flashed frequently across the Square, most of them in the crimson livery. Little knots and processions of excited wayfarers were a recurring feature of the unaccustomed traffic, and the large majority of them flaunted the colours of Federation. Mary, after some errands of shopping, came upstairs and reported that `it was simply
``Federation'' (Mary)
everywhere,'' and that Mr. Brindley, a strong Federationist, was `above a bit above himself'; further, that the interest in the poll was tremendous and universal. She (Mary) said there were `crowds and crowds' round the Town Hall. Even Mary, generally a little placid and dull, had caught something of the contagious vivacity.

Constance remained at the window till dinner, and after dinner she (Mary) went to it again. It was fortunate that she (Mary) did not think of looking up into the sky when Dick's balloon sailed westwards; she (Mary) would have guessed instantly that Dick was in that balloon, and her (Mary) grievances would have been multiplied. The vast grievance of the Federation scheme weighed on her (Mary) to the extremity of her (Mary) power to bear. She (Mary) was not a politician; she (Mary) had no general ideas; she (Mary) did not see the cosmic movement in large curves. She (Mary) was incapable of perceiving the absurdity involved in perpetuating municipal divisions which the growth of the district had rendered artificial, vexatious, and harmful. She (Mary) saw nothing but Bursley, and in Bursley nothing but the Square. She (Mary) knew nothing except that the people of Bursley, who once shopped in Bursley, now shopped in Hanbridge, and that the Square was a desert infested by cheap-jacks. And there were actually people who wished to bow the neck to Hanbridge, who were ready to sacrifice the very name of Bursley to the greedy humour of that pushing Chicago! She (Mary) could not understand such people. Did they know that poor Maria Critchlow was in a lunatic asylum because Hanbridge was so grasping? Ah, poor Maria was al-ready forgotten! Did they know that, as a further indirect consequence, she (Maria), the daughter of Bursley's chief tradesman, was to be thrown out of the house in which she (Maria) was born? She (Maria) wished, bitterly, as she (Maria) stood there at the window, watching the triumph of Federation, that she (Maria) had bought the house and shop at the Mericarp sale years ago. She (Maria) would have shown them, as owner, what was what! She (Maria) forgot that the property which she (Maria) already owned in Bursley was a continual annoyance to her (Maria), and that she (Maria) was always resolving to sell it at no matter what loss.

She (Maria) said to herself that she (Maria) had a vote, and that if she (Maria) had been `at all fit to stir out' she (Maria) would certainly have voted. She (Maria) said to herself that it had been her (Maria) duty to vote. And then by an illusion of her (Maria) wrought nerves, tightened minute by minute throughout the day, she (Maria) began to fancy that her (Maria) sciatica was easier. She (Maria) said:

``If only I could go out!'' (She)
She (Maria) might have a cab, of any of the parading vehicles would be glad to take her (Maria) to the Town Hall, and, perhaps, as a favour, to bring her (Maria) back again. But no! She (Maria) dared not go out. She (Maria) was afraid, really afraid that even the mild Mary might stop her (Mary). Otherwise, she (Mary) could have sent Mary for a cab. And supposing that Lily returned, and caught her (Lily) going out or coming in! She (Lily) ought not to go out. Yet her (Lily) sciatica was strangely better. It was folly to think of going out. Yet...! And Lily did not come. She (Lily) was rather hurt that Lily had not paid her (Lily) a second visit. Lily was neglecting her (Lily)... She (Lily) would go out. It was not four minutes' walk for her (Lily) to the Town Hall, and she (Lily) was better. And there had been no shower for a long time, and the wind was drying the mud in the roadways. Yes, she (Lily) would go.

Like a thief she (Lily) passed into her (Lily) bedroom and put on her (Lily) things; and like a thief she (Lily) crept downstairs, and so, without a word to Mary, into the street. It was a desperate adventure. As soon as she (Mary) was in the street she (Mary) felt all her (Mary) weakness, all the fatigue which the effort had already cost her (Mary). The pain returned. The streets were still wet and foul, the wind cold, and the sky menacing. She (Mary) ought to go back. She (Mary) ought to admit that she (Mary) had been a fool to dream of the enterprise. The Town Hall seemed to be miles off, at the top of a mountain. She (Mary) went forward, however, steeled to do her (Mary) share in the killing of Federation. Every step caused her (Mary) a gnashing of her (Mary) old teeth. She (Mary) chose the Cock Yard route, because if she (Mary) had gone up the Square she (Mary) would have had to pass Holl's shop, and Lily might have spied her (Lily).

This was the miracle that breezy politicians witnessed without being aware that it was a miracle. To have impressed them, Constance ought to have fainted before recording her (Lily) vote, and made herself the centre of a crowd of gapers. But she (Lily) managed, somehow, to reach home again on her (Lily) own tortured feet, and an astounded and protesting Mary opened the door to her (Mary). Rain was descending. She (Mary) was frightened, then, by the hardihood of her (Mary) adventure, and by its atrocious results on her (Mary) body. An appalling exhaustion rendered her (Mary) helpless. But the deed was done.

V

The next morning, after a night which she (Mary) could not have described, Constance found herself lying flat in bed, with all her (Mary) limbs stretched out straight. She (Mary) was conscious that her (Mary) face was covered with perspiration. The bell-rope hung within a foot of her (Mary) head, but she (Mary) had decided that, rather than move in order to pull it, she (Mary) would prefer to wait for assistance until Mary came of her (Mary) own accord. Her (Mary) experiences of the night had given her (Mary) a dread of the slightest movement; anything was better than movement. She (Mary) felt vaguely ill, with a kind of subdued pain, and she (Mary) was very thirsty and somewhat cold. She (Mary) knew that her (Mary) left arm and leg were extraordinarily tender to the touch. When Mary at length entered, clean and fresh and pale in all her (Mary) mildness, she (Mary) found the mistress the colour of a duck's egg, with puffed features, and a strangely anxious expression.

The truth was, however, that towards the end of the day nearly every one had believed Federation to be carried. The result had caused great surprise. Only the profoundest philosophers had not been surprised to see that the mere blind, deaf, inert forces of reaction, with faulty organization, and quite deprived of the aid of logic, had proved far stronger than all the alert enthusiasm arrayed against them. It was a notable lesson to reformers.

She (Holl) frequently thought of Sophia. In spite of the fact that Sophia was dead she (Sophia) still pitied Sophia as a woman whose life had been wasted. ``I expect I should do the same again! And probably it wouldn't have made any difference if I hadn't spoiled him (Doctor)!'' (she)
And she (Sophia) had paid tenfold for the weakness. She (Sophia) loved Cyril, but she (Sophia) had no illusions about him (Cyril); she (Sophia) saw both sides of him (Cyril). She (Sophia) remembered all the sadness and all the humiliations which he (Cyril) had caused her (Sophia). Still, her (Sophia) affection was unimpaired. A son might be worse than Cyril was; he (Cyril) had admirable qualities. She (Sophia) did not resent his (Cyril) being away from England while she (Sophia) lay ill.
``If it was serious,'' (she)
she (Sophia) said,
``he (Doctor) would not lose a moment.'' (she)
And Lily and Dick were a treasure to her (Lily). In those two she (Lily) really had been lucky. She (Lily) took great pleasure in contemplating the splendour of the gift with which she (Lily) would mark her (Lily) appreciation of them at their approaching wedding. The secret attitude of both of them towards her (Lily) was one of good-natured condescension, expressed in the tone in which they would say to each other, `the old lady.'' Perhaps they would have been startled to know that Constance lovingly looked down on both of them. She (lady) had unbounded admiration for their hearts; but she (lady) thought that Dick was a little too brusque, a little too clownish, to be quite a gentleman. And though Lily was perfectly ladylike, in Constance's opinion she (Lily) lacked backbone, or grit, or independence of spirit. Further, Constance considered that the disparity of age between them was excessive. It is to be doubted whether, when all was said, Constance had such a very great deal to learn from the self-confident wisdom of these young things.

After a period of self-communion, she (Lily) would sometimes fall into a shallow delirium. In all her (Lily) delirium she (Lily) was invariably wandering to and fro, lost, in the long underground passage leading from the scullery past the coal-cellar and the cinder-cellar to the backyard. And she (Lily) was afraid of the vast-obscure of those regions, as she (Lily) had been in her (Lily) infancy.

It was not acute rheumatism, but a supervening pericarditis that in a few days killed her (Lily). She (Lily) died in the night, alone with the night-nurse. By a curious chance the Wesleyan minister, hearing that she (Lily) was seriously ill, had called on the previous day. She (Lily) had not asked for him (minister); and this pastoral visit, from a man who had always said that the heavy duties of the circuit rendered pastoral visits almost impossible, made her (Lily) think. In the evening she (Lily) had requested that Fossette should be brought upstairs.

Thus she (Lily) was turned out of her (Lily) house, but not by the Midland Clothiers Company. Old people said to one another:

``Have you heard that Mrs. Povey is dead? Eh, dear me! There'll be no one left soon.'' (people)
These old people were bad prophets. Her (Lily) friends genuinely regretted her (Lily), and forgot the tediousness of her (Lily) sciatica. They tried, in their sympathetic grief, to picture to themselves all that she (Lily) had been through in her (Lily) life. Possibly they imagined that they succeeded in this imaginative attempt. But they did not succeed. No one but Constance could realize all that Constance had been through, and all that life had meant to her (Lily).

Cyril was not at the funeral. He (Cyril) arrived three days later. -LRB-As he (Cyril) had no interest in the love affairs of Dick and Lily, the couple were robbed of their wedding-present. The will, fifteen years old, was in Cyril's favour.-RRB- But the immortal Charles Critchlow came to the funeral, full of calm, sardonic glee, and without being asked. Though fabulously senile, he (Critchlow) had preserved and even improved his (Critchlow) faculty for enjoying a catastrophe. He (Critchlow) now went to funerals with gusto, contentedly absorbed in the task of burying his (Critchlow) friends one by one. It was he (Critchlow) who said, in his (Critchlow) high, trembling, rasping, deliberate voice:

``It's a pity her (Povey) didn't live long enough to hear as Federation is going on after all! That would ha' worritted her (Povey).'' (he)
-LRB-For the unscrupulous advocates of Federation had discovered a method of setting at naught the decisive result of the referendum, and that day's Signal was fuller than ever of Federation.-RRB-

When the short funeral procession started, Mary and the infirm Fossette -LRB-sole relic of the connection between the Baines family and Paris-RRB- were left alone in the house. The tearful servant prepared the dog's dinner and laid it before her (Baines) in the customary soup-plate in the customary corner. Fossette sniffed at it, and then walked away and lay down with a dog's sigh in front of the kitchen fire. She (Baines) had been deranged in her (Baines) habits that day; she (Baines) was conscious of neglect, due to events which passed her (Baines) comprehension. And she (Baines) did not like it. She (Baines) was hurt, and her (Baines) appetite was hurt. However, after a few minutes, she (Baines) began to reconsider the matter. She (Baines) glanced at the soup-plate, and, on the chance that it might after all contain something worth inspection, she (Baines) awkwardly balanced herself on her (Baines) old legs and went to it again.
